pros:
If you manage to get into USAA, you will have a sense of security, unless the CEO and the Board decide to sell off more parts of the company.

In certain areas of the company you will have the opportunity to learn and grow, and be put in positions to showcase your abilities or potential.

Benefits are decent, although they have dramatically declined over the past 2 years.

Education benefits are a plus, if you want to earn your first or additional degree.
cons:
In the past five years at the company, it has dramatically declined since I joined the company. What attracted me to the company was its history of having shared military values, and knowing what it meant to serve. Upon retiring from the military, this was a rare characteristic in any company, and gravitated to USAA due this reason. 

Since the time Stewart Parker took over as CEO, the company declined in almost every facet. And continues to part ways from its former self under Wayne Peacock. 

With Stewart Parker pushing to make USAA Federal Savings Bank categorized as a Big Bank, it put the entire collection of companies that make up USAA at risk, and it came to fruition when the CFPB’s fine, and the OCC’s consent order. He essentially tried to sell a house without it being built, and got dinged on being out of compliance for a bank of its size class. With that USAA has engaged in correcting those gaps and deficiencies, but took a strange approach to it. They started to actively seek out executives and individual contributors from companies that have egregious violations in the banking industry, and place them in the 2nd and 3rd lines of defense areas (Risk, Compliance, and Audit). This has put USAA in a circle of on-going and repetitive activities that have no end-state, all in the sake of compliance. Thus increasing the work load, and decreasing work-life balance and productivity.

review_title: USAA is still finding the balance
pros: Benefits are world class: 8% 401k match (100% vested in just 2 years), free onsite gym with steam room, sauna, and showers, onsite clinic, cafeteria, massage therapy, great corporate culture, 2 volunteer days per year, generous PTO, effective training program (they pay for your licensing), tuition benefit of up to $10k per year on just about anything you want to major in, management seems pretty invested in success of employees, breaks go beyond the state guidelines (CO requires 2 paid 10s and an unpaid 30- USAA gives an extra 25 minutes of paid break beyond that). It is hourly instead of salary, so there is the benefit of being paid for any extra time you have to work beyond your scheduled hours. There's also a 30% premium for weekends and evenings, as well as a holiday bonus each year worth an entire paycheck. The TOTAL compensation package is quite generous.
cons:
The entry level adjuster job is kind of a joke. We're more phone operators than anything, and you must remain in this mundane, waste-of-my-talent position for a full year before being allowed to move up or around. There is ZERO file ownership. You can pay the easiest of claims, but if you can't pay on the first call, you have to pass the file on to a higher level adjuster. Tracking phone adherence is a little frustrating, because if I get a call right before a scheduled break and have to take my break later, technically I'm out of adherence for that time until I have a manager go in and adjust it. It should really be more based on the total number of minutes you're supposed to be "Ready", not down to the specific minute. Finally, the pay is pretty insulting for the level of talent they hire for these positions. You're basically forced to rely on the company bonus every year to bring you up to industry standards, and there is no way to plan for how much you'll get because it varies every year. ALSO- the hiring schedule felt like it was intended to screw us a little. We were brought on right after the first of the year, which meant we lost out on flex days off that are granted right at the beginning of the year, and though the company advertises benefits with reduced premiums for Healthy Points, employees hired right after the beginning of the year do not get to have their Healthy Points discount until the following year. So I came on thinking I'd be able to score some points for being a fit individual and pay $96 less per month, only to learn I'll be paying full premiums until next year since I wasn't able to earn my points last year.
Advice to Management
Provide a more relaxed avenue for talented entry-level employees to demonstrate their skills and move into the positions for which we are really qualified. The fact that I cannot see myself in this banal entry-level position for a year is causing me to consider leaving the company altogether. Also, employees across the board would rather have a higher base salary every check than have to wait for a bonus each year to bring us up to industry standards. Particularly when employees who joined expecting great things are struggling to make ends meet due to the pay cut on the biweekly check as compared with other companies (an insurance company right across the street starts adjusters at almost $8k more per year, which is a lot more than my bonus would have been this year if I'd gotten one).
